content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple sections of tissue on the slide. Based on their round-to-oval shape and dense basophilic (purple) appearance, these are characteristic of lymph nodes embedded in lighter pink-staining adipose (fat) and fibrous tissue. There are at least four to five distinct lymph node profiles. My initial task is to systematically examine each lymph node for evidence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The zoom area is located at the periphery of the largest lymph node on the left. I am zooming into this specific region for two critical reasons: 
1. To examine the subcapsular sinus, which is the area just beneath the lymph node capsule. This is a very common initial site for metastatic carcinoma cells to deposit after arriving via lymphatic drainage. 
2. To assess the integrity of the lymph node capsule and look for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the capsule into the surrounding fat. The interface between the lymph node and the pericolic fat is the key location to evaluate for ENE, a significant prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would zoom into this specific area because it is located at the periphery of a lymph node, at the interface between the lymphoid parenchyma and the surrounding perinodal fat and connective tissue. This subcapsular sinus region and the perinodal lymphatics are the most common initial sites for metastatic tumor cells to deposit. A thorough examination of this interface is critical to detect small metastatic foci that might not be apparent at low magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the standard procedure for staging colorectal cancer involves examining every lymph node submitted to rule out metastasis. I would systematically review each node at higher magnification. The green box is placed on the most inferior lymph node within the larger cluster on the left. This zoom is part of that systematic examination to assess the cellular architecture and cytology of this specific node for any evidence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node to screen for metastatic cancer cells. I zoomed into this specific area on the lymph node located on the right because it appears abnormal at low power. Unlike the surrounding uniform dark purple lymphoid tissue, this region shows a focal, irregular, paler pink area. This change in color and texture suggests a disruption of the normal lymph node architecture and is highly suspicious for infiltration by metastatic carcinoma, which is typically more eosinophilic than lymphoid tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the edge of the lymph node on the upper left, characterized by a dense population of lymphocytes and some reactive follicles. On the lower right, there is fibro-adipose tissue (fat and connective tissue) with some small blood vessels. I am carefully inspecting the interface between these two tissues. I do not see any atypical cells, nests of tumor, or glandular structures that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma in this specific field of view. The lymph node appears to be reactive, and there is no evidence of tumor invasion into the surrounding fat (no extranodal extension). My impression of this particular area is that it is benign/negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, the top portion shows the dense infiltrate of lymphocytes characteristic of a lymph node cortex. The lower portion consists of perinodal fibro-adipose tissue. Within this perinodal connective tissue, and potentially within lymphatic channels, there are several small nests and clusters of atypical epithelial cells. These cells have enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei with irregular contours and eosinophilic cytoplasm. My impression is that these are metastatic adenocarcinoma cells. This finding confirms that this is a positive lymph node, and the presence of tumor cells in the perinodal fat is indicative of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoom-in area, I see a dense and polymorphous population of lymphoid cells, consistent with the parenchyma of a lymph node. The cells are predominantly small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and dark nuclei. There are some subtle variations in density, suggesting follicular and interfollicular areas. I do not see any definite clusters of atypical large cells, glandular formations, or extensive necrosis that would be suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that it represents a reactive lymph node, which is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I can see residual normal lymphoid tissue (dense, small, dark lymphocytes) being infiltrated and replaced by irregular nests and poorly formed glands of malignant cells. These malignant cells are much larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, with abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and large, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. The arrangement in nests and glands is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with a primary colorectal cancer. The metastatic deposit appears to be a macrometastasis.
